Detente and national security can they compromise
By JOE GRIFFITH
Much has been said about the benefits
of our so-called "detente" with the Soviet
Union. Perhaps the most popular is the
"convergence" myth, whereby detente is
perceived to be the force by which the
Soviet Union is to be liberalized and the
nations of the Atlantic community are to
become increasingly socialized. The
merits a dangers of the latter' will not be
addressed here. However, disapproval of
the liberalization leg upon which this
myth rests will be sufficient to collapse at
least this one chimera about detente.
Also, it may serve to put a damper on
many of the other inflated claims for
detente.
The necessity for detente in the eyes of
Leonid Brezhnev is extremely logical.
Whereas our motivations revolve around a
concern for the world as we would like it
to be: peaceful, balanced, convergent,
etc., Brezhnev is attempting to use
detente to solve some very concrete
political problems. The Soviets believe
the Chinese at this time to be the greatest
threat to their security not only in terms
of a convential or nuclear war, but also in
view of the instability the Chinese could
engender in those Soviet territories on the
Chinese border. The gradual acceptance
by the Western bloc of the East European
status quo, in which the Soviets have had
a continual interest, culminated in the
recent Helsinki Accord.
The problem of the East European
status quo is not the only thing affected
by the "Chamberlainesque" performance
of Ford and Kissinger in Finland. This
agreement is viewed by many Soviets and
East European dissidents, as well as
Western conservatives, as a signal of
general acceptance of the "Brezhnev
Doctrine." This strategy in essesnce
allows Soviet intervention in Eastern
Europe to "preserve socialism." Socialism
was "preserved" in East Germany in
. in Hungary in 1956, and in
1953,
Czechoslovakia in 1968.
It is interesting to note that the
"preserver" of socialism during the East
German worker's uprising in 1953, Adrei
Grechko, is now the head of the Soviet
Armed Forces and is a member of the
Politburo of the Soviet Union
Community Party, the committee which
rules the Soviet Union. Another "hero of
socialist preservation" is Yuri Andropov,
who is a member of the Politburo and the
head of the Soviet internal security and
espionage apparatus, the KGB. Andropov
was ambassador to Hungary from 1954 to
1957.
The "Brezhnev Doctrine" reserves the
right to defend Eastern Europe from
"subversive Western influence" such as
freedom of movement and
communication which, while included in
the Helsinki Accord, were in fact
generalized out of existence.
More important though, the "Brezhnev
Doctrine" reserves the right to exert
Soviet influence in Western Europe.
Portugal, a NATO country, is an obvious
example. This policy is sometimes
ironically referred to as "Finlandization."
It is entirely consistent with the Soviet
conception of detente as having
"significance only for 'relations between
states'," I and having "no bearing on
continuing Soviet support for
anti-Western forces within other states."
In reality the Soviet Union has gained
very substantiftlly on the!international
level in return for some very intangible
assurances concerning civil rights. The
question of the self determination of
countries such as the Baltic States was
not even broached at the Helsinki
Conference, much less Soviet expansions
in other parts of the world.
The second basic problem which

Brezhnev faces is the inability of the
Soviet system to meet the rising material
expectations of the broad base of Soviet
society with either the present or
projected productive ability of the Soviet
economy. This problem calls for one of
two solutions. Either the Soviet Union
could radically alter its highly centralized
and coercive economic and governmental
system to make it more efficient and
more answerable to consumer demands or
it could attempt to import Western
consumptive and capital goods and
technology. The latter course is known in
Russia as "Computer Communism" or
"Stalinism with Computers."

Before discussing the costs of both
options,Ithe assumption that the Soviet
economy in and of itself can expand and
satisfy the outgrowing demands placed
upon it should be exposed. In fact the
rate of growth in industrial productivity
has been falling steadily in the last twenty
years. As noted Soviet scientists Sakharov
and Medvedev have pointed out, there is
an "essential and ever-growing gap
between our country and the West
extending through the entire spectrum of
scientific-technological activity."
Stagnation is not restricted to the
industrial sector, as is indicated by the
size and incidence of grain purchases

The recent death of Dr. Hillard Berger
incites me to write on a topic that will
eventually touch us all.
Because we are human we will die.
Someday. If we are lucky our end will be
quick, hopefully happening during sleep.
Others will have to endure an arduous
bout with a terminal illness whose
outcome will seem anticlimactic. But
whatever the route, the end result will be
the same: we shall all be snapped from
life, leaving friends, lovers, and children
behind, crying.
When we are young and the days are
sunny, it is perhaps inappropriate to
consider our' mortality. Yet mortal we
are, vulnerable to death, the sole
equalizer of men. In one way, death is
intrinsically apolitical yet democratic—it
knows no economic, racial or cultural
bias—it prefers everyone. It is not swayed
oy need or intellectual promise, it does
not seem reasonable, and I believe it is
somewhat vain to even hypothesize on its
nature. But for personal reasons I feel
compelled to write on this subject which
has had such profound impact on this
stage of my development.
When someone you love dies, a part of
you dies with him. But only a part. True,
there is a time in life reserved for
mourning, but this emotion should not be
so all-encompassing that we deny
ourselves the right to live our own lives
after that time has passed. Ideally, the
death of one close should instill in us a
special verve, a heightened respect for all
that continues to live, and a profound
appreciation of life for life's sake.
Indeed, I have found that death brings
out the humanity in man. At no other
time in life does compassion flow so
freely and with such genuine intent than
it does when death strikes a family. For a

while, the apparently vile world that
robbed you of a dear companion becomes
an old friend, nourishing you with
memories of happier times. You realize
how enriched you are by the dead one;
you may even choose to pursue his ethic.
And in a sense, this course cannot be
avoided, since that person is an
inseparable component of your own
being.
Death brings a flood of sympathy.
Though it may seem impotent—it cannot
restore a life—in its pure form sympathy
is a vital buffer between the initial shock
of death and the reality of having to live
with loss. For a few days, everyone is
your friend, and no one is reluctant to
offer you all the assistance possible.
But the real trial comes in the weeks
following the funeral, when the
condolences stop rolling in, when the
relatives return hour, and the gap once filled
by the dead one remains vacant. Slowly
you realize that death is the ultimate
Goodbye.
Death is not necessarily evil. To the
incurably ill,it may be the answer to months
of prayer. It can mean relief from
excruciating pain or ardent anxiety, but
whenever it strikes—in the battlefield or
to the innocent child—it must be
acknowledged for its utter solemnity.
Reflecting on the deaths of both my
parents, I cannot believe that something
as intrinsically fascinating and beautiful
as life can end abruptly at death. There
must be a continuance, some, form of
spiritual perpetuation. But I will never
know for sure until my final hour. It is
this mystery that will maintain death as
the final taboo: no one has ever returned
from the dead except for one person.
And even then it was not long before He
returned to the celestial necropolis when
He came.

The radical alteration of the Soviet
economy would entail three things. It
would divert a great deal of investment
away from the expansion of conventional
military capacity which is now going on
at a tremendous rate relative to the U.S.
It would require a radical reorganization
of the Soviet governmental bureaucracy.
And it would entail a tacit admission that
there was something wrong with the
system and by implication would detract
from the legitimacy of the Party in the
eyes of the people and from its ability to
control Soviet society.
The first step is opposed by the
military for reasons familiar to most
Americans. The second would place the
secure position of the Soviet bureaucracy
in jeopardy, which when attempted by
Krushchev, contributed to his ouster. The
third would require the partial
dismantling of the coercive organs of the
Soviet state which have an interest in
their own preservation as is notably
pointed out in Solzhenitsyn's Gulag
Archipelago. Not only do they possess
the universal bureaucratic trait of
self-preservation, but they also represent
the most ideologically motivated of
Soviet institutions. For them any
decentralization of the socialist state, any
loosening of control, is, in Andropov's
words, "the undermining of Soviet power
from within."
Unable to pursue the radical course
because opposition from the three most
powerful groups in the Soviet government
would be political suicide for him,
Brezhnev is engaged in a political
tightrope act which we call detente.
Detente, especially the trade and
investment opportunities, allows the
Soviet government to balance the
material aspirations of the society while
also satisfying the demands of the major
governmental interest groups.
Implicit in this formula is not the
"liberalization" of Soviet society, but
rather the strengthening of a system,
economic and political, which is having
difficulty standing on its own two feet. In
fact the indications are that from an
organizational standpoint, control over
the society is being strengthened and even
more centralized, i.e. totalized. This
movement, termed "neo-Stalinization," is
underscored by the growing gulf between
Party members and the rest of the
populace, by the superficial or
centralizing nature of most
reorganization, by the increasing
suppression of the intelligentsia and of
non-Russian nationalities, by the
increasing population of the Central
Committee of the Part with military and
KGB personnel, and by the piore
favorable regard in which Stalin is today
being held.
These domestic implications of detente
can be viewed and are viewed by
dissidents in Eastern Europe as an
outgrowth of the generally uncritical
attitude towards detente on Soviet terms
by Western leaders, media and business as
well as political. A critical attitude
towards detente should not be
overwhelmed by the Kissinger juggernaut
at the expense of our strategic security
and Russian civil rights. Alternatives,
briefly stated here and largely ignored
elsewhere, would involve exacting more
for our contribution to what is now
essentially an unbalanced trade-off or
assuming a policy of benign neglect
towards the Soviet regime. Such a policy
might eventually weaken it to the point
where it would be forced to change itself
or be overthrown.

Put the current situation in perspective.
Spanish Sahara is the last of what was

Spain, under pressure from Third World

With a . convincing 1-0 victory over
Division I rival Georgetown Wednesday
afternoon at Homewood, the Blue Jay
Varsity Soccer team moved one step
Closer to a possible NCAA post-season
playoff bid.
The start of the game was delayed
nearly half an hour due to the late arrival
of the Hoyas. Once the contest did get
underway, however, it appeared as
though the visitors had left their offense
back on the Washington Beltway.
Hopkins totally controlled the first
fifteen minutes of the match as they
bombarded the Georgetown goal with
Shot after shot. Meanwhile, Hopkins
goalie Ken Seusse did not face a Hoya
Shot during this same period of time.
The Jays scored the game's only goal at
the 16:26 mark of the apening half. Gary
Ignatowski passed the ball to Greg
Cunningham, who proceeded to dribble
Past several defenders and rifle a shot past
the helpless Hoya netminder.
The flow of play for the remainder of
the half was very similar to the pattern
that had already been established.
Hopkins made the game appear to be a
half-field sc-rimmage to set up any scoring
oPportunities. At halftime, the Jays held
a 20-4 margin in shots on goal and goalie
Seusse had not been forced to make a
save.
Play resumed in the second forty-five

minutes where it had left off after the
first. The Jays continued their shot
barrage—although they failed to add to
their lead—and the defense continued its
stranglehold on the Hoyas offense.

9-1-1) with a 37-11 lead in shots and
Seusse making only three saves en route
to his fifth shutout of the season.

pleased with the team's performance.
"We dominated it [the game] in every
aspect," he declared. "We had plenty of
chances, but could only put the ball in
the goal once."

defensive corps.

Oliver noted. "Cazzy [Bruce Cazenave]
did a fine job as our rover back and Lou
[Podrazik] and Frank [Olszewski]
played very steady games."

the Blue Jays of an NCAA tournament
bid. They must play tough Washington
College (9-2) tomorrow in an away
contest that may decide which team will
see post-season action.

twenty-goal scorer so far this season, and
goalkeeper Pete Murphy. Their losses
have been to Loyola and Swarthmore, a

running for the four bids from this region

winner is found.

secure position of the Soviet bureaucracy
in jeopardy, which when attempted by
Krushchev, contributed to his ouster. The

dismantling of the coercive organs of the
Soviet state which have an interest in

the universal bureaucratic trait of
self-preservation, but they also represent
the most ideologically motivated of

decentralization of the socialist state, any
loosening of control, is, in Andropov's
words, "the undermining of Soviet power
from within."
Unable to pursue the radical course
because opposition from the three most
powerful groups in the Soviet government
would be political suicide for him,
Brezhnev is engaged in a political
tightrope act which we call detente.

investment opportunities, allows the
Soviet government to balance the
material aspirations of the society while
also satisfying the demands of the major
governmental interest groups.

difficulty standing on its own two feet. In

organizational standpoint, control over
the society is being strengthened and even

increasing population of the Central

Georgetown succumbs to Jay Rooters
By DAVID KRAUS
With a . convincing 1-0 victory over
Division I rival Georgetown Wednesday
afternoon at Homewood, the Blue Jay
Varsity Soccer team moved one step
Closer to a possible NCAA post-season
playoff bid.
The start of the game was delayed
nearly half an hour due to the late arrival
of the Hoyas. Once the contest did get
underway, however, it appeared as
though the visitors had left their offense
back on the Washington Beltway.
Hopkins totally controlled the first
fifteen minutes of the match as they
bombarded the Georgetown goal with
Shot after shot. Meanwhile, Hopkins
goalie Ken Seusse did not face a Hoya
Shot during this same period of time.
The Jays scored the game's only goal at
the 16:26 mark of the apening half. Gary
Ignatowski passed the ball to Greg
Cunningham, who proceeded to dribble
Past several defenders and rifle a shot past
the helpless Hoya netminder.
The flow of play for the remainder of
the half was very similar to the pattern
that had already been established.
Hopkins made the game appear to be a
half-field sc-rimmage to set up any scoring
oPportunities. At halftime, the Jays held
a 20-4 margin in shots on goal and goalie
Seusse had not been forced to make a
save.
Play resumed in the second forty-five

minutes where it had left off after the
first. The Jays continued their shot
barrage—although they failed to add to
their lead—and the defense continued its
stranglehold on the Hoyas offense.
Final statistics showed Hopkins (now
9-1-1) with a 37-11 lead in shots and
Seusse making only three saves en route
to his fifth shutout of the season.
Homewood Coach Bob Oliver was
pleased with the team's performance.
"We dominated it [the game] in every
aspect," he declared. "We had plenty of
chances, but could only put the ball in
the goal once."
The coach had special plaudits for his
defensive corps.
"Ami Cohen did an admirable job,"
Oliver noted. "Cazzy [Bruce Cazenave]
did a fine job as our rover back and Lou
[Podrazik] and Frank [Olszewski]
played very steady games."
The victory, however, does not assure
the Blue Jays of an NCAA tournament
bid. They must play tough Washington
College (9-2) tomorrow in an away
contest that may decide which team will
see post-season action.
Washington is led by Billy Williams, a
twenty-goal scorer so far this season, and
goalkeeper Pete Murphy. Their losses
have been to Loyola and Swarthmore, a
pair of teams that Hopkins has defeated,
while among their wins is a victory over
George Washington, a squad that downed

the Jays in pre-season play.
"A lot rides on Saturday's game,"
Coach Oliver explained. "The NCAA has
allowed regional chairmen to wait until
Sunday before making their decision,
which will be announced on Monday."
"I was informed by the Southern
chairman that there are eight teams in the
running for the four bids from this region
and that we're one of the eight."
An interesting sidelight of tomorrow's
contest is that it cannot end in a tie. It's
an MAC conference match, and under
league rules the teams must continue to
play in sudden death overtime until a
winner is found.
